The Dark Wood series #1 – Giuseppe Spezzano of Bookolico

By: Irene Cassarino
31-10-2012
bookolico, the dark wood series

Bookolico is a startup that wants to innovate the way books are published, distributed and read, starting from Italy – and Italian language. Bookolico offers independent writers and small publishers the opportunity to escape traditional distribution channels (which also include Amazon-like giants) and to keep a much higher percentage from the shelf price of the e-book. The price itself of the e-book is expected to grow according to the e-book popularity (number of downloads), until a maximum amount.

Bookolico has emerged to the web surface as a landing page in March 2012, and launched as a beta in August 2012. Bookolico is very young and intrinsically unstable: it’s not anymore an idea sketched on an iPad screen, and a successful company neither. Every startup goes through this sort of limbo, where sudden issues and unexpected satisfactions mark the daily rhythm, and when you are barely too busy keeping calm and facing such a wave motion to realize that the baby is actually growing and getting stronger.

If the story of a startup was a book, we see this limbo as an extremely interesting chapter to read.
That’s why we are introducing a new series of interviews to founders in the middle of the journey of their startup’s life, where we ask them to report about the way they live and feel the beat of their creature. We are fond of epics, we see startuppers as heroes: having been grown up with Dante, we name this series “The Dark Wood“!

Today the mic goes to Giuseppe Spezzano, founder of Bookolico.

In the middle of the journey of Bookolico‘s life…

Tell me please about the three major issues and three major achievements that you got since the conception of the project Bookolico till now

Issues:
1. To find collaborators, namely developers. Luckily Davide (the backend developer – he’s rapidly putting Bookolico up with cake php) is always with me, but we are struggling to find people eager to help. I mean: with the right attitude, welcoming the chance to join a startup’s team as a real opportunity, you know…
2. To evaluate whether to incorporate or not to incorporate, and how. At the end we decided not to. Bookolico is still a group of private citizens.
3. To push the idea from the ‘paper’ (the iPad sketch book, actually) throughout the development process

Achievements:
1. Visibility and success on social networks: even though Bookolico is still in its beta and the value proposition is still unstable, and despite the operational issues we are facing every day, in less than 6 months from the launch of the landing page and 2 months from the release of the beta, Bookolico has 800 followers on Twitter and 1000 likes on Facebook. I am also quite impressed that I have been invited as speaker at a conference where I will be sitting at the same round table with Feltrinelli (among the biggest publishers in Italy)
2. The release of the landing page: the success we got with the concept of the “Fingerfood for dreams” was so significant that we decided to keep it also after the launch of the beta
3. The launch of the beta, indeed. I know it may sound banal but I never took it for granted!

How do you make your living? Does Bookolico gives you enough money to sustain yourself?

You crazy. My father: that’s how I make it.

Why does conversation with users matter?

The relationship with the community and all the members of it is paramount. Bookolico is its community.
We aspire to build an environment which stands as an alternative to the traditional editorial world. Such an environment is a community.
For now I would say we have built an initial network, not yet a community.

What will make the network a community?

I am currently exploring gamification mechanics and corresponding behaviors.

Amazon wants to buyout Bookolico. What do you do?

Tough question, and quite early … but you are right: they tell you that even before having developed the concept you should have your exit strategy very clear.
I really don’t know, though.
OK, I feel that Bookolico is just a start: is this enough as an answer?

So you decided not to incorporate, yet. Why?

Because founding and maintaining a company in Italy is expensive. Too dear.
At the other end, you may be someone on the Web regardless of your juridical identity.

Do you have a business plan?

Nope. I don’t even think I will ever craft one. It’s a waste of time. Numbers you put in it are usually random. Best thing is to go straight to the market and collect real numbers there.

Do you have a cash flow plan?

Are you kidding me?:)

Can you tell me a good thing and and bad thing about being entrepreneur in Italy?

Good thing… mmmh… OK I got it: you don’t have to face a fierce competition. You don’t need that much to stand out if you have a good and innovative idea. In a dusty and old world, to innovate is easier than elsewhere.

Bad thing: it’s difficult.

You mean, tiring?

Indeed: tiring, expensive… and the bureaucracy… you know it.

The start-up ecosystem in Turin: again, a good and bad thing.

Good: I have a distinct feeling that it’s a good place to give birth to new ideas.
Bad: It is still not enough to make these new ideas grow and accelerate into sustainable entrepreneurial plans and initiatives.

What about your experience of collaboration with us?

Good: you gave me a full support. Not only technical, but also moral, emotional. You’ve been always available to listen and to give good advise.
Bad: slowness in progresses and improvable organization. But I reckon it was not your only fault: it’s also because we have been badly organized ourselves.

Your main concern about the future of Bookolico:

To drain resources out before having tapped the threshold of sustainability. And for resources I especially mean people.

What does drive you forward?

Rewards and recognitions from users, fans, institutions.

Has something changed along the concept development, from the original idea until now?

Sure. First of all, the concept of publisher: at the beginning we thought that writers, private citizens, would have been the main source of books in Bookolico. Now we are turning our attention to small publishers.
The gamification mechanics are also a new entry with respect to the original concept.

Interview happened before lunch, which was based on
- soup of cabbage and carrots
- selection of Piemontese cheeses (Castelmagno, Toma, etc)
- grissini

Giuseppe is a slow and calm eater and a very enjoyable company, who discovered a slight form mistrust toward strongly flavored nordic cheeses.

evento ntrct n. 13, 11 ottobre: ordalia

By: paolo
12-10-2012
Just Italian, ntrct

ginnastica

tutte cose sono così, l’uso fa la cosa, la gonfia, la riempie, l’invera; e lo stomaco, mangiando troppo, si fa più grande; l’ozio ha bisogno di riposo, il sesso di godere, l’intelligenza cerca di capire, la vita vuole vivere, l’occhio vedere
e di disuso si nutre atrofia: dei sedentari i muscoli si ritirano, dei pigri s’appesantisce il qulum, di noi senza ntrct scolora il senso, il gusto per quelle storie, e gli incontri;
o no?

in queste settimane di silenzio vi ho messo alla prova, enigmaticamente, un po’ stronzamente, lo ammetto, ma vi ringrazio, molti di voi mi hanno scritto, anche nell’intimità di una mail, altri hanno pubblicato cose, domande, c’è chi me l’ha detto in faccia, dai, e dai, che fai? è ora di ricominciare, a scrivere, per incontrarsi

il prossimo ntrct evento; ci state?
giovedì, così, senza preavviso, una cosa un po’ al brucio, questo, questo giovedì, alle 8.30, che ne dite della boheme, chiediamo la saletta dei tini

Programma?
incontrarsi
leggere
scrivere?
parlare di paratissima, che ci hanno invitati (ci avevano anche invitati al Bunker di via Paganini, ma non si trovò la data nemmeno)

REGOLA x questa volta
Leggeremo ognuno 1 racconto, scegliendo da quelli già scritti, a meno che ci sia anche roba nuova, certo, è evidente, ma forse non ci sarà, e allora riprendiamo le fila, scegline uno, dei tuoi, e leggerai quello, ognuno uno e ci incontreremo, per scrivere, vino e candele, il tappeto no, quello non potrò portarlo, nemmeno il baule, temo, e i libretti? portatevi i vostri, io ne faccio altri, se riesco

Tacatì – sustainable grocer…

Tacatì – sustainable grocery for smart&busy people!

By: Irene Cassarino
08-10-2012
backend, English, Tacati

Tacatì conveys a traditional product through an innovative experience. Once again, innovation is attached to service and to user experience.

The product is locally-sourced grocery. Mainly food, but also cleaners, articles for personal and body care etc.
Community supported agriculture (c.s.a.), indeed, is not a new thing. The traditional c.s.a. service though have few rigidities, which Tacatì translates into opportunities and an innovative service model.

Rigidity n.1 – offer: lack of flexibility with the variety of products and the quantity you can order. Usually c.a. boxes are made of a fixed quantity of goods (usually family-sized), whose composition varies according to the season and the availability of the single producer that source them.

Rigidity n.2 – lifestyle: lack of flexibility with the delivery times and places. Boxes are delivered at working times for the producer and for you as well, typically at your place or in gathering places that are difficult to reach. Unless you don’t work at home/you can easily leave you office for a while, it’s quite difficult to catch the box and the user experience become a nightmare.

Rigidity n.3 – prices: lack of flexibility in the selection and the substitution of producer or in adding a new one, which also implies a very limited competition and a sort of monopoly which tend to keep prices at the upper side of the market.

Tacatì gathers local producers ( = whose production site is less than 100km away from your place) and conveys their offers into a single web shop: you browse the offer, fill your e-cart with the exact quantities that fit your specific weekly needs, choose a delivery place – it can be your place, your office or a gathering point nearby -, pay with your credit card and wait for the box!

Deliveries happen once per week. Prices are much lower than the corresponding product at the supermarket (while quality is higher!) and gathering places can be user generated: if you have a refrigerator too big for your personal/family/business needs, you can offer your place/office/shop to host some of Tacati deliveries and get a percentage of the shipping price!

Last but not least, Tacatì has a federal architecture: if you feel like selecting and organizing a network of local producers around your city and set-up a similar service for your fellow citizens, you can contact Giulia and Stefano and borrow their web platform (and experience!!) to start a new, sustainable and smart business adventure! Tacati is always in search for partners!
